Award.AwardTitle: Induced Electrodeposition of Molybdenum and Tungsten Alloys
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Elizabeth J. Podlaha of Northeastern University is supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Division of Chemistry to study the mechanisms of induced electrochemical codeposition of molybdenum and tungsten alloys from aqueous solutions, and to use these alloys in a nanowire architecture to catalyze electrolytic hydrogen production. The alloys will be reduced under photoelectrochemical excitation and the composition of the resulting deposit will be characterized. The mechanisms will be examined by impedance techniques, including intensity-modulated photocurrent and intensity-modulated photovoltage spectroscopy, and the structure of the deposit will be characterized by surface analytical methodologies. A mathematical model to predict deposit composition will be developed.

Electrodeposition has contributed greatly to magnetic data storage and computer technology, but it is emerging as a uniquely capable method for making materials and structures needed for a nanotechnology-based future economy. Although electrochemical deposition has been utilized for a very long time, the mechanisms of electrodeposition at the atomic level are not clearly understood. Students will be trained in electrochemical deposition and catalysis, and a website will be developed to demonstrate electrodeposition for high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the electrodeposition of alloys, groups of alloys are often categorized by their unusual reduction characteristics. Induced codeposition describes one such family represented by alloys containing molybdenum (Mo) and tungsten (W), fabricated by electrochemically reducing their ions from water. The induced codeposition of Mo and W is interesting from a fundamental point of view because without the catalysis of another element, particularly nickel (Ni), iron (Fe), or cobalt (Co), then Mo and W cannot be reduced from water at all. From a practical standpoint, films containing Mo and W are of interest for a variety of applications, for example: as a catalyst for enhancing hydrogen generation from water splitting reactions, as corrosion resistant films, and to improve hardness in thin films for surface treatment of tools. Being able to electrodeposit them helps to broaden applications to the micro and nano-domains as they can be readily deposited into nano-porous templates or photolithographically prepared surfaces. Understanding the induced codeposition behavior is essential to not only control alloy composition and thickness, but also to gain knowledge in electrodeposition behavior that can be extended to other alloy systems with unusual reduction behavior. Our project (1) developed novel Ni-Mo-W alloys, (2) found that there is a peferential deposition of Mo vs W in a Ni-alloy deposit, (3) developed models to describe negative reaction orders of Ni and W ion reduction with molybdate in determining the deposit compositon, (4) holds the "world's record" for the largest amount of Mo induced by the codeposition of Ni in a NiMo alloy, (5) electrodeposited novel Ni-W and Fe-Co-W nanowires and (6) devised a new impedance technique with modulated UV light to detect semiconductive intermediates.

An effort was made to create environmentally more sound electrolytes by eliminating ammonium ions that have been traditionally used in Mo and W alloy plating.


Last Modified: 02/08/2018
Modified by: Elizabeth J Podlaha

Being able to electrodeposit them helps to broaden applications to the micro and nano-domains as they can be readily deposited into nano-porous templates or photolithographically prepared surfaces. Understanding the induced codeposition behavior is essential to not only control alloy composition and thickness, but also to gain knowledge in electrodeposition behavior that can be extended to other alloy systems with unusual reduction behavior. Our project (1) developed novel Ni-Mo-W alloys, (2) found that there is a peferential deposition of Mo vs W in a Ni-alloy deposit, (3) developed models to describe negative reaction orders of Ni and W ion reduction with molybdate in determining the deposit compositon, (4) holds the "world's record" for the largest amount of Mo induced by the codeposition of Ni in a NiMo alloy, (5) electrodeposited novel Ni-W and Fe-Co-W nanowires and (6) devised a new impedance technique with modulated UV light to detect semiconductive intermediates.
